turn.text: One is a one is a baseball game, another is a concert, another is is a lecture on on dinosaurs, and another is political speech.

turn.speaker: richard_l_wilson
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Wilson
turn.text: If there are competing applications and one of them is a free speech event and one of them is a softball game, and the decision is made based on what the free speech event is urging, what the message is, that is entirely inappropriate.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It, if you....

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I agree completely.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But just supposing all you know about it is, they want to make s- it's a political rally of some kind on the one hand, baseball, music, all those can the content, without any hostility to the particular message, be one of the criteria that can can break ties?

turn.speaker: richard_l_wilson
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Wilson
turn.text: If your question assumes that each of those events would be appropriate for that specific...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: location...

turn.speaker: richard_l_wilson
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Wilson
turn.text: then no.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'd like to reserve the remainder of my time.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Strauss, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: has been...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: the earlier application to be accepted,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: at least not as I read it.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, first come, first serve if the application is is valid, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It is required to be accepted? W- Which one of those says that.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, it- i- the a valid applica-, a fully executed prior application for a permit has been received, and a...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: permit has been granted...

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's a reason for denial,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: doesn't say the converse, that it must be accepted if it's earlier.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, the a the , the only ground for denial there are other ground- possible grounds for denial, but one ground for denial is someone was there first.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, it it works out that way because of the provision that says applications shall be processed...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: in the order of receipt.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So will effectively be...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I don't see I really don't see it, and I'm not sure it's commanded, either, but...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I guess...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think that that's constitutionally required that it be a first come, first serve rule?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, it is our system, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Can you ask for the park three years in advance?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: My understanding, Justice Scalia, is that we have a practice, although I don't know if it's in, if it's written down anywhere, of not accepting applications for more than some period of time in advance,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think six months.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There's some some provision...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: whole scheme is written on the basis that the permit may be denied, and there are a set of criteria, but it doesn't appear to be any affirmative requirement that anything be granted if it meets all the requirements.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Oh, Justice O'Connor, we we we do have to grant it if it meets those requirements.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: May deny.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: may deny is an authorization to the park district to deny in these circumstances.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And not otherwise.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And and it doesn't do anything to govern how you grant competing applications, other than the fact that you say there is some kind of built in first come, first serve basis.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: The way the competing applications are handled is on a first come, first serve basis.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: One one of the objections made by the petitioner was that either in this case or, reading the regulations, you don't have to give written reasons.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: respond to that.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Justice Kennedy, we do provide reasons.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That was my and you did in this case?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes, we did, in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This is...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: based on on previous damage and material misrepresentations in the earlier...

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: application.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: regulations require that you give the reasons?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes, they do.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: It then goes on to say that where feasible, thif- if there is a com- if there is a competing use the park district will propose a way to accommodate the accomodate the use.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Could you explain the the degree of discretion to grant, in the event that the conditions are not satisfied?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the park district's -- Late.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: A late application, application that's not submitted.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Would there have been discretion in this case? Regar- Let's assume the only prior violation had been the the the fact that if that earlier gathering people were still hanging around at eleven o'clock, after the park or after eleven when the park closed.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes, there would have been, if we had concluded that if if if the applicant said to us something that gave us reason to believe it wouldn't happen again, or if the nature of the event were such that if was scheduled earlier in the day, or something like that, that it wouldn't happen again, or if it happened again it wouldn't be so much of a problem, but we don't assert, and I don't think you can assert, consistent with the ordinance, a kind of free floating discretion to overlook violations for people we like and not for people we don't like.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Does the record tell us how many permits are granted and how many denied each year...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: by the park?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, on the grants, the record, the the most precise number we have in the record is there are thousands of applications and thousands of grants a year.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about denials?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Denials, Justice O'Connor, is a hard number to come up with, and this bears on the Freedman versus Maryland point, because what often happens is that the denial takes the form of saying, well we can't accommodate you at this space at this time, but if you're willing to move your event a week later, or willing to move it to this alternative site, then we can accommodate you.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: not involving speech.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: a permit was denied to Mr. McDonald based on some prior event where people stayed after eleven o'clock.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, it was denied for multiple reasons.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There was also...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: administrative mechanisms in place for someone who wants to challenge the basis for the denial...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yup-

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: administratively?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes, there is, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I take it that's the second distinction from Freedman.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, the second distinction Freedman while that that is a distinction, Justice Souter, but the second distinction really is that a a a key premise of Freedman is that the decision in question was one that the courts had superior competence to make, and that the agency was to be distrusted in making.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: participation...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Does the same problem get injected by the exception clause in the ordinance, that in fact they can waive conditions if there would be a First Amendment violation?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Justice Souter, that that clause, t- two two things about that clause are are salient, I think.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and the second thing...

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Which happened here.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And the third distinction that you want to rely on?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: The third distinction, Justice Souter, is that in the Freedman context the Court had indicated a strong preference for after the fact regulation, that if the co- if a community is concerned about obscenity, the way to regulate that is by after the fact criminal prohibitions.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Strauss, you've ably distinguished Freedman, but do you think that none of the procedural safeguards that were involved in Freedman are applicable here, from here starting with the basic, the the administrator has to have some time limit to act on these petitions to hold events?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, I would put that part of Freedman in a different category.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I I think there's considerable merit, what you have just said, although at the end of your brief you you make the final argument that this is really not a speech statute anyway.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: which, of course...

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Or a zoning permit, variance of some kind, which, of course, apply to expressive activities, but to a lot of other activities, too.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I suppose the easy way to answer...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: that argument is to say we've never done this with reference to parks.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, that's right, Justice Kennedy, but as some of the questions from the Court suggested during my colleague's argument, because these are parks, perhaps the Government has more leeway than it would have in telling people what they can do on their own property.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you did say that you you feel some impulsion from the First Amendment to have a, have to make a decision within a set time to guard against abuse of discretion.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, I think well, for anyone claiming a violation of a constitutional right, there should be an avenue for prompt judicial review, and I , further, I think that part of Freedman is intended to deal the situation like that present in some of this Court's cases, in FW PBS and in Shuttlesworth in particular, a situation where the applicant can't be quite sure when the permit's been denied, so so so the applicant doesn't quite know when it's okay to go to court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: ways. It can also be challenged...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: you have those provisions in means it's a little different from the ordinary zoning ordinance or business license, because those are all motivated by c- First Amendment concerns, I assume.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: prior restraint? Or are you just ducking the issue?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: No, Justice Stevens, I don't I don't I wouldn't I wouldn't want to duck the issue.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So if s- if something like this is to be considered valid, what are the limits to make it reasonable as a regulation? We've already mentioned prompt action should be required, perhaps, by the park.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: If the Court does not accept our argument that this is more like a business license,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: then yes, prompt action or a specified time for action by...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the administrator.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: And an opportunity for prompt judicial review, that's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Otherwise, just, I'm sorry...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: adequacy of judicial review? I take it one objection was that you don't get any actual hearing in court.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, my reading of the Illinois cases is that that's not true even in State court and, of course, the pet- the applicant has the option of going to the Federal court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Strauss.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well do you think we should view it as Mr. Strauss urges, as a zoning ordinance, or a business license, or as some kind of content-neutral time, place, and manner restriction?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I I think more the latter.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It would make it a lot fairer, wouldn't it? I mean, if if, you either meet the criteria, or you don't.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The a- the the problem would be exactly the...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: kind of thing that Mr. Strauss described, is that if there is a minor if if you put in your permit application slightly too late, or there was a stray mark on your application, requiring total strictness on any of these criteria would just mean that people who really should be entitled to have the opportunity to speak...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, they didn't foll- follow the rules.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: But I think...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why don't you just say, these are the rules,

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: if you come in late, you haven't complied with the rules, period.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think as I think as Mr. Strauss I think it was Mr. Strauss said, the the the the that is whatever the flexibility or discretion that remains in a system like this would be exe- has to be exercised in accordance with those grounds for denial.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: you can...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How do you say it doesn't frustrate the purpose of of the provision which says, you know, the the thing has to be in, you know, two weeks beforehand, if you get it in one week beforehand? How can you possibly say that doesn't frustrate the the purpose of the provision? The purpose is to give you two weeks to consider it.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Right, but I I think well, you could, it could well be that the purpose is to make sure that the park district can guarantee it can consider it, but if they if it comes in on a day, one day late but there's nothing else on top of it that they're waiting to consider, if it's in the wintertime when they have very few permit applications, they can get to it anyhow, and there's no reason for them not to permit that use of the park.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In any event, that's...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: from that, I assume there's no way to write a regulation that is not going to require some some judgment, some discretion.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I I think that's right, and I think a crucial feature of this requirement is that, if, of the ordinance here is that the parks are used for multiple uses by multiple people.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would it be...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That should be addressed on a on a on an as applied basis, and and I think it could be in the State court proceedings, or in a nineteen eighty-three proceeding.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Along the lines of Justice Scalia's question, would it be proper for a city council or municipality to draft an ordinance just like this one and then, then at the end saying, the commissioner of parks, in his sole discretion, may waive any or all of the foregoing requirements?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think the the only difficul- it would depend on what that meant.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, we've said in in a case like Forsyth that the s- discretion has to has to have s- h- have some definition and some control to it, and if you have at the end an an absolute waiver provision, s- it seems to me that would contradict that.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Oh, I I think well, I think that's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: guided...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How do, where where does it say that that the may, the may grant anyway is limited to those applications that generally meet the purposes of the st-, where does it say that? Do we just take your word for it?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or or the park district's word for it?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think that that would at least be the most reasonable construction of an ordinance like this, where there's a- a- attempt to detail these thirteen specific criteria quite specifically, and there's no suggestion that there's any other basis on which the park district can act, and it it, I I think that that's just the most reasonable interpretation of this kind of ordinance.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: to all.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Federal regulations for the use of Federal parks, the use of the Mall, do they differ with respect to the may deny?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But there is the...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: the may deny, implying that there are cases where, although you could, you don't have to deny?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And and no criteria for the waiver in the Federal s-

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: in the Federal scheme either?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: way those are, have consistently been applied is, those are the grounds that are suppose, to be considered i- in determining whether you can grant a permit, and there aren't other grounds on which a permit would be denied.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And and i- is there a first come, first serve rule?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Basically, yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Feldman.

turn.speaker: richard_l_wilson
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Wilson
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, I'd like to address quickly two points that you raised.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: prompt judicial review...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: does that mean if you pick the Fede- Federal court, that Illinois is going to write a statute that says, and if you choose to come to the Federal court rather than the State court, the Federal court is going to have X number of days to decide it?

turn.speaker: richard_l_wilson
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Wilson
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, that would be the choice of the park district of the City of Chicago, because the park district is the is the party that has to go to court to seek...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Oh, if if...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: you're but that's not what Justice O'Connor said in in her case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: take that last part of Freedman.

turn.speaker: richard_l_wilson
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Wilson
turn.text: But there's certainly a distinction between those businesses that Justice O'Connor was writing about in FW PBS and a...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: core political speech.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: your notion that the scheme is invalid unless the park goes to court, and the court has a tight time line?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We...

turn.speaker: richard_l_wilson
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Wilson
turn.text: I would then say, Justice Ginsburg, that this Court has elevated the kind of sexually explicit speech in that case above the core political speech in this case, based on the content of the speech, which would fly in the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: face of...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: follow that at all.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Wilson.
